articles.snippet: Basic cellphones line up for a Simplicity Derby, but are they efficient?
articles.abstract: Basic cellphones line up for a Simplicity Derby, but are they efficient?
articles.lead_paragraph: And now, an exclusive peek inside the in-box of a technology columnist.

articles.headline: The Ascent of Wind Power
articles.snippet: Wind power is emerging as an alternative in fast-growing countries like India and China that are avidly seeking new energy sources.
articles.abstract: Wind power is emerging as an alternative in fast-growing countries like India and China that are avidly seeking new energy sources.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHORI, India — Dilip Pantosh Patil uses an ox-drawn wooden plow to till the same land as his father, grandfather and great-grandfather. But now he has a new neighbor: a shiny white wind turbine taller than a 20-story building, generating electricity at the edge of his bean field.

articles.headline: The Newspaper Publisher Who Said No to More Cuts
articles.snippet: In refusing job cuts at The Los Angeles Times, publisher Jeffrey M. Johnson has transformed himself in the eyes of Times employees.
articles.abstract: In refusing job cuts at The Los Angeles Times, publisher Jeffrey M. Johnson has transformed himself in the eyes of Times employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a year ago, the Tribune Company told The Los Angeles Times to cut millions of dollars from the paper’s budget and get rid of hundreds of jobs. The top editor and the publisher complied.

articles.headline: Rural Areas Left in Slow Lane of High-Speed Data Highway
articles.snippet: Big phone and cable companies are reluctant to expand in rural areas, leaving millions without high-speed access.
articles.abstract: Big phone and cable companies are reluctant to expand in rural areas, leaving millions without high-speed access.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANAAN, Vt. — For most businesses, the goal is to attract as many customers as possible. But in the fast-changing telephone industry, companies are increasingly trying to get rid of many of theirs.

articles.headline: If Not G.M., Says Ghosn, Maybe Ford
articles.snippet: Carlos Ghosn’s comments came hours after he met with General Motors’ chief executive, Rick Wagoner.
articles.abstract: Carlos Ghosn’s comments came hours after he met with General Motors’ chief executive, Rick Wagoner.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 27 — Carlos Ghosn, who runs the automakers Renault of France and Nissan of Japan, said Wednesday that he would still be interested in adding a North American partner if discussions with General Motors failed to bring about an alliance — raising the prospect of eventual talks with the Ford Motor Company.

articles.headline: Ex-H.P. Officer to Say She Knew of No Illegality
articles.snippet: Patricia C. Dunn is expected to testify today at a Congressional hearing.
articles.abstract: Patricia C. Dunn is expected to testify today at a Congressional hearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 — In her most detailed account of the leak investigation that forced her to resign, Hewlett-Packard’s former chairwoman maintains that while she was in regular contact with those conducting the operation, she was not its supervisor.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Damon Darlin

articles.abstract: The Democrats suddenly face a map with unexpected opportunities in their battle for control of the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27   Six weeks before Election Day, the Democrats suddenly face a map with unexpected opportunities in their battle for control of the Senate.

articles.headline: Air Force Jet Wins Battle in Congress
articles.snippet: The F-22 Raptor fighter jet, a Maserati of the skies, has just taken on Washington budget-cutters, and won, thanks to a powerful lobby.
articles.abstract: The F-22 Raptor fighter jet, a Maserati of the skies, has just taken on Washington budget-cutters, and won, thanks to a powerful lobby.

articles.headline: Ex-H.P. Officer to Say She Knew of No Illegality
articles.snippet: In her most detailed account of the leak investigation that forced her to resign, Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman maintains that while she was in regular contact with those conducting the operation, she was not its supervisor.      In prepared...
articles.abstract: In her most detailed account of the leak investigation that forced her to resign, Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman maintains that while she was in regular contact with those conducting the operation, she was not its supervisor.      In prepared remarks that she is expected to deliver Thursday at a Congressional hearing, Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman who resigned from the board last week, also said she never had reason to believe that illegal methods were used. And she said she repeatedly sought assurances on that point from those directly involved.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - In her most detailed account of the leak investigation that forced her to resign, Hewlett-Packard's former chairwoman maintains that while she was in regular contact with those conducting the operation, she was not its supervisor.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Damon Darlin

articles.headline: If Not G.M., Says Ghosn, Maybe Ford
articles.snippet: Carlos Ghosn, who runs the automakers Renault of France and Nissan of Japan, said Wednesday that he would still be interested in adding a North American partner if discussions with General Motors failed to bring about an alliance -- raising the pr...
articles.abstract: Carlos Ghosn, who runs the automakers Renault of France and Nissan of Japan, said Wednesday that he would still be interested in adding a North American partner if discussions with General Motors failed to bring about an alliance -- raising the prospect of eventual talks with the Ford Motor Company.     Mr. Ghosn's remarks came hours after he met with G.M.'s chief executive, Rick Wagoner, at Renault's headquarters in the Paris suburb of Boulogne-Billancourt.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 27 - Carlos Ghosn, who runs the automakers Renault of France and Nissan of Japan, said Wednesday that he would still be interested in adding a North American partner if discussions with General Motors failed to bring about an alliance -- raising the prospect of eventual talks with the Ford Motor Company.

articles.headline: The Ascent of Wind Power
articles.snippet: Dilip Pantosh Patil uses an ox-drawn wooden plow to till the same land as his father, grandfather and great-grandfather. But now he has a new neighbor: a shiny white wind turbine taller than a 20-story building, generating electricity at the edge ...
articles.abstract: Dilip Pantosh Patil uses an ox-drawn wooden plow to till the same land as his father, grandfather and great-grandfather. But now he has a new neighbor: a shiny white wind turbine taller than a 20-story building, generating electricity at the edge of his bean field.     Wind power may still have an image as something of a plaything of environmentalists more concerned with clean energy than saving money. But it is quickly emerging as a serious alternative not just in affluent areas of the world but in fast-growing countries like India and China that are avidly seeking new energy sources. And leading the charge here in west-central India and elsewhere is an unlikely champion, Suzlon Energy, a homegrown Indian company.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHORI, India - Dilip Pantosh Patil uses an ox-drawn wooden plow to till the same land as his father, grandfather and great-grandfather. But now he has a new neighbor: a shiny white wind turbine taller than a 20-story building, generating electricity at the edge of his bean field.

articles.headline: The Newspaper Publisher Who Said No to More Cuts
articles.snippet: Less than a year ago, the Tribune Company told The Los Angeles Times to cut millions of dollars from the paper's budget and get rid of hundreds of jobs. The top editor and the publisher complied.     But when Tribune came calling last month to see...
articles.abstract: Less than a year ago, the Tribune Company told The Los Angeles Times to cut millions of dollars from the paper's budget and get rid of hundreds of jobs. The top editor and the publisher complied.     But when Tribune came calling last month to seek a new round of cuts, Jeffrey M. Johnson, the publisher, and Dean Baquet, the editor, had had enough. They refused to make what they considered drastic cuts and said so publicly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a year ago, the Tribune Company told The Los Angeles Times to cut millions of dollars from the paper's budget and get rid of hundreds of jobs. The top editor and the publisher complied.

articles.headline: DEMOCRATS CITE NEW HOPE IN BID TO RETAKE SENATE
articles.snippet: Six weeks before Election Day, the Democrats suddenly face a map with unexpected opportunities in their battle for control of the Senate.     In Virginia, a state that few expected to be seriously competitive, Senator George Allen looks newly vuln...
articles.abstract: Six weeks before Election Day, the Democrats suddenly face a map with unexpected opportunities in their battle for control of the Senate.     In Virginia, a state that few expected to be seriously competitive, Senator George Allen looks newly vulnerable after a series of controversies over charges of racial insensitivity, strategists in both parties say. In Tennessee, another Southern state long considered safely red, Representative Harold E. Ford Jr., a Democrat, has run a strong campaign that has kept that state in contention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 - Six weeks before Election Day, the Democrats suddenly face a map with unexpected opportunities in their battle for control of the Senate.

articles.headline: For Kazakh Leader’s Visit, U.S. Seeks a Balance
articles.snippet: When Vice President Dick Cheney came to this oil-rich Central Asian nation this spring he expressed admiration for what he called its ''political development.'' Yet just a day before his visit began, the authoritarian government effectively shut d...
articles.abstract: When Vice President Dick Cheney came to this oil-rich Central Asian nation this spring he expressed admiration for what he called its ''political development.'' Yet just a day before his visit began, the authoritarian government effectively shut down the two most prominent American democracy organizations working here.     While American officials are negotiating to reverse the government's decision, they have yet to complain about it publicly.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Ilan Greenberg

articles.headline: Some Phones Are Just, Well, Phones
articles.snippet: And now, an exclusive peek inside the in-box of a technology columnist.     ''Dear Mr. Pogue: You've reviewed cellphones that play music, record video, receive TV channels and do e-mail. But here's a radical idea: What about cellphones that make p...
articles.abstract: And now, an exclusive peek inside the in-box of a technology columnist.     ''Dear Mr. Pogue: You've reviewed cellphones that play music, record video, receive TV channels and do e-mail. But here's a radical idea: What about cellphones that make phone calls?
articles.lead_paragraph: And now, an exclusive peek inside the in-box of a technology columnist.

articles.headline: Rural Areas Left in Slow Lane of High-Speed Data Highway
articles.snippet: For most businesses, the goal is to attract as many customers as possible. But in the fast-changing telephone industry, companies are increasingly trying to get rid of many of theirs.     Bill and Ursula Johnson are among the unwanted. These dairy...
articles.abstract: For most businesses, the goal is to attract as many customers as possible. But in the fast-changing telephone industry, companies are increasingly trying to get rid of many of theirs.     Bill and Ursula Johnson are among the unwanted. These dairy farmers in bucolic northeastern Vermont wake up before dawn not just to milk their cows, but to log on to the Internet, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANAAN, Vt. - For most businesses, the goal is to attract as many customers as possible. But in the fast-changing telephone industry, companies are increasingly trying to get rid of many of theirs.

articles.headline: As 2 Bushes Try to Fix Schools, Tools Differ
articles.snippet: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida has long played the dutiful younger brother.     Well before President Bush signed his No Child Left Behind law, Jeb Bush poured his own ideas into a school improvement program for Florida.
articles.abstract: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida has long played the dutiful younger brother.     Well before President Bush signed his No Child Left Behind law, Jeb Bush poured his own ideas into a school improvement program for Florida.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. - Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida has long played the dutiful younger brother.

articles.headline: Air Force Jet Wins Battle in Congress
articles.snippet: The F-22 Raptor fighter jet, the United States Air Force's most expensive weapon, is designed for global air dominance. But its biggest battles have not been in the skies, but in the corridors of power in Washington, where it has just taken on Def...
articles.abstract: The F-22 Raptor fighter jet, the United States Air Force's most expensive weapon, is designed for global air dominance. But its biggest battles have not been in the skies, but in the corridors of power in Washington, where it has just taken on Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Washington budget-cutters -- and won.      Since coming into office, Mr. Rumsfeld and the administration have tried to rein in the costs of the $65 billion fighter jet program, which has been two decades in the making and has suffered one cost overrun after another.
